4.speaker: Wyll
4.text: Today, a sacrifice must be made. I trust in you to lead us down the right path.

6.speaker: Wyll
6.text: Hells - you are Bhaalspawn. It explains so much.

123.speaker: Wyll
123.text: Listen to me. I knew another like you - Gorion's Ward, one of Baldur's Gate's great heroes. Bhaal's blood ran through their veins too.

260.speaker: Wyll
260.text: They burned away their own darkness with their own inner light. They chose courage, they chose honour - and so can you.

8.speaker: Wyll
8.text: Thousands were sacrificed, and the servant become lord. I am sure Astarion's quite pleased with himself.

12.speaker: Wyll
12.text: Damned goblins. Monsters, every last one - the kind I was culling from Sword Coast hamlets just a tenday ago.

16.speaker: Wyll
16.text: Minsc, the great ranger. He's alive - and infected? Hells. We need to act.

17.speaker: Wyll
17.text: You slurped that thing up like a horse with a carrot.

377.speaker: Wyll
377.text: Not that I'm one to question someone's meal preferences, but something tells me this is more than a dietary quirk.

342.speaker: Player
342.text: Tell Wyll about the orb in your chest, and how it came to be there.

352.speaker: Player
352.text: The magic in those objects helps maintain my spellcasting talents.

351.speaker: Player
351.text: Tell Wyll the story of your orb. Leave nothing out.

413.speaker: Wyll
413.text: Ah - you drank of the goblet of godhood. Not even a dwarf could distil a liquor more addictive.

178.speaker: Wyll
178.text: And now you carry doom itself within you as penance. My father would lecture you on the perils of power-lust -

3.speaker: Wyll
3.text: - but that's not a lesson that needs repeating, I wager.

47.speaker: Wyll
47.text: Consume all the magic artefacts you need to keep that bomb of yours from exploding.

318.speaker: Wyll
318.text: All right. Far be it from me not to take you at your word.

59.speaker: Player
59.text: I don't want to talk about it.

18.speaker: Wyll
18.text: Githyanki are impressive - cold as ice, when they're not blazing hot. I wager Lae'zel's no exception.

19.speaker: Wyll
19.text: I see the hunger in your eyes, and I see how it worries you.

75.speaker: Wyll
75.text: But you are stronger than the hunger. You can resist, you will resist. I'm sure of it.

20.speaker: Wyll
20.text: Gods - have we really cut down the Great Ranger Minsc? A nightmare that can never be erased from my memory.

21.speaker: Wyll
21.text: Erm - as glad as I am to have the hammer, I'm not so sure a devil's deal was the way to go here.

246.speaker: Wyll
246.text: 'I hope you know what you're doing' would be the trite thing to say here, but... it suits the occasion.

29.speaker: Wyll
29.text: Ngh. Sights I've never known, joined by smells I could never have imagined.

30.speaker: Wyll
30.text: Today, a sacrifice must be made. I trust in you to lead us down the right path.

35.speaker: Wyll
35.text: Dammit all, we've got to get Halsin back. If that means killing Gortash, nothing would give me greater pleasure.

300.speaker: Wyll
300.text: But we've got to tread carefully. I won't risk my father's life to take Gortash's.

37.speaker: Wyll
37.text: An impostor in our camp? We must identify them - and quickly. Without trust, our fellowship is doomed to wither and die.

43.speaker: Wyll
43.text: Bhaal's chosen has been bled. May her torment be tenfold of that which she inflicted.

45.speaker: Wyll
45.text: A veritable angel, chained and tortured for centuries. To think she was so close to freedom.

255.speaker: Wyll
255.text: Unfettered slaughter, no more and no less. I thought better of Shadowheart. That was mistake.

46.speaker: Wyll
46.text: The gith knight is as merciless as the dragon he rides. That we still have our heads is nothing short of a miracle.

50.speaker: Wyll
50.text: The source of Gortash's Watchers. If I could get over my disgust, I might be impressed.

54.speaker: Wyll
54.text: Such soothing light here, as if Selûne herself was caressing my skin.

55.speaker: Wyll
55.text: Dammit all, we've got to get Lae'zel back. If that means killing Gortash, nothing would give me greater pleasure.

283.speaker: Wyll
283.text: But we've got to tread carefully. I won't risk my father's life to take Gortash's.

57.speaker: Wyll
57.text: Raphael's good and gone - feels damn good, too. Now if only I could get rid of the other devil in my life...

58.speaker: Wyll
58.text: Jaheira would do anything to see her family safe. They're lucky to have her - and she's lucky to have them.

61.speaker: Wyll
61.text: An anti-lantern that radiates darkness and not light? Clever idea. Unnerving, too.

66.speaker: Wyll
66.text: Incredible to be back. My home, my city.

67.speaker: Wyll
67.text: I hope that's the end of this silly quarrel. They'll have no energy for battling our enemies if Lae'zel and Shadowheart are too busy squabbling among themselves.

78.speaker: Wyll
78.text: Vlaakith's a fearsome one. The sort it's hard to say 'no' to.

64.speaker: Wyll
64.text: But Lae'zel said it anyway, to her immense credit. She's choosing truth, she's choosing freedom - for her, for Orpheus, for the githyanki people.

62.speaker: Wyll
62.text: I wish I knew a good githyanki cheer to celebrate the occasion, but the only gith phrases I've picked up are the sweary sort.

81.speaker: Wyll
81.text: Gods, poor Zevlor - even good intentions can lead us down deadly paths.

83.speaker: Wyll
83.text: Hold close to the light, and keep the shadows at bay.

89.speaker: Wyll
89.text: Raphael thought he could outsmart us - but there are other ways to get the Orphic Hammer, guaranteed.

375.speaker: Wyll
375.text: We know he keeps it in the House of Hope. If we can find a diabolist, they could help us make our way in.

90.speaker: Wyll
90.text: Welcome to the Lower City, where Baldur's Gate truly comes alive.

92.speaker: Wyll
92.text: Astarion has a certain swagger, don't you find? An interesting fellow. Nice hair, to boot.

94.speaker: Wyll
94.text: Defile Vlaakith's name, and even a gith knight can't avoid the wrath of the mighty Lae'zel.

97.speaker: Wyll
97.text: The Plane of Shadow. My tutor called it a dark mirror held up to our own plane of existence, a perversion of all we hold dear.

347.speaker: Wyll
347.text: I thought she was exaggerating. And I was wrong.

100.speaker: Wyll
100.text: Our very own vampire's the missing pawn in his master's deadly game.

101.speaker: Wyll
101.text: This True Soul Nere's stuck behind a rockfall, is he? Forgive me if I'm in no hurry to go digging him out.

102.speaker: Wyll
102.text: Shadowheart's memories will be a heavy load for her to carry.

201.speaker: Wyll
201.text: But her suffering is over - and so is her parents'. I hope she finds comfort in that.

108.speaker: Wyll
108.context: NodeContext: Deep disappointment, almost to the point of heartbreak, that SH went the evil route.

71.speaker: Wyll
71.text: An old fairy tale my father read to me. The kind with a hero, a villain, and a moral.

95.speaker: Wyll
95.text: A farmer made a deal with a devil, so the story goes: in exchange for the farmer's dearest fruit, the devil granted him a bottomless coinpurse.

412.speaker: Wyll
412.text: The farmer's dearest fruit, naturally, was no apple nor peach, but his beloved daughter.

237.speaker: Wyll
237.text: We can learn a lot from fairy tales, don't you think?

11.speaker: Player
11.text: With the right teacher, yes. What are your thoughts on the devil, Wyll?

326.speaker: Wyll
326.text: Refuse him, no matter how tempting the offer, no matter how delicious the feast he lays out for you. The cost's always too great.

1.speaker: Player
1.text: Don't worry. I have no interest in a devil's deal.

124.speaker: Wyll
124.text: That's because you still have hope. But when he becomes your last hope, remember this.

335.speaker: Wyll
335.text: He'll require of you only what you're least ready to part with.

254.speaker: Wyll
254.text: You might think you'd give up anything for a cure.

219.speaker: Wyll
219.text: But the devil won't take just anything. He'll take everything.

272.speaker: Player
272.text: He spoke of a cure. We have to at least hear him out.

383.speaker: Wyll
383.text: Take a single step towards him, and he'll dog you the whole journey.

103.speaker: Player
103.text: No cost is too great, if it rids me of this infection.

52.speaker: Player
52.text: Refuse him like you refused Mizora? Only, you didn't, did you?

88.speaker: Wyll
88.text: I made a mistake. This is your chance to learn from it.

155.speaker: Player
155.text: The devil made an empty promise. Our only hope lies with my people.

87.speaker: Wyll
87.text: A devil wouldn't bargain if he thought there was no chance of success, Lae'zel.

107.speaker: Wyll
107.text: Trust me: he'll take what you're least ready to part with.

376.speaker: Wyll
376.text: Do not trust a devil. Is that plain enough?

173.speaker: Player
173.text: You mean Raphael? We should at least consider his offer, given our circumstances.

156.speaker: Player
156.text: Spare me the parables - I've no intention of bargaining with the likes of him.

341.speaker: Player
341.text: Interesting, coming from someone who's already been ensnared by a devil.

216.speaker: Wyll
216.text: Who better to warn you of the danger ahead?

109.speaker: Wyll
109.text: You have conquered your urge, you have taken back your own soul. I'm so proud of you.
109.context: NodeContext: Deep disappointment, almost to the point of heartbreak, that SH went the evil route.

294.speaker: Wyll
294.text: If I had a bottle of Dragondew, I'd open it in your honour.

112.speaker: Wyll
112.text: Karlach never ceases to amaze me.
112.context: NodeContext: Deep disappointment, almost to the point of heartbreak, that SH went the evil route.

93.speaker: Wyll
93.text: Death is staring her down. And she want these last moments to count for something.

266.speaker: Wyll
266.text: But there's another option to consider: Orpheus.

387.speaker: Wyll
387.text: We can break him free. He might give us options we hadn't thought of, opened doors that we thought were closed.

232.speaker: Wyll
232.text: But - if Karlach wants to go make these last moments count, then don't hold her back.

118.speaker: Wyll
118.text: Kill a hellbeast, unveil the truth. Raphael may be a scoundrel, but it's too good a deal to refuse.
118.context: NodeContext: Deep disappointment, almost to the point of heartbreak, that SH went the evil route.

119.speaker: Wyll
119.text: A shame my first brush with the famed Elminster couldn't be a tad more... optimistic.
119.context: NodeContext: Deep disappointment, almost to the point of heartbreak, that SH went the evil route.

120.speaker: Wyll
120.text: Ketheric Thorm is no more. And may he stay dead, this time.
120.context: NodeContext: Deep disappointment, almost to the point of heartbreak, that SH went the evil route.

128.speaker: Wyll
128.text: Breathe, focus. This battle's barely begun.
128.context: NodeContext: Deep disappointment, almost to the point of heartbreak, that SH went the evil route.

131.speaker: Wyll
131.text: A good wizard is hard to find. Let's make Gale feel welcome, as best we can.
131.context: NodeContext: Deep disappointment, almost to the point of heartbreak, that SH went the evil route.

132.speaker: Wyll
132.text: I've rarely had to venture this far below the surface. Rare is the under-beast that takes to the sun.
132.context: NodeContext: Deep disappointment, almost to the point of heartbreak, that SH went the evil route.

134.speaker: Wyll
134.text: Astarion showed restraint where most others wouldn't. He might not appreciate the sentiment - but I'm proud of him.
134.context: NodeContext: Deep disappointment, almost to the point of heartbreak, that SH went the evil route.

137.speaker: Wyll
137.text: So our half-elf ally's heart belongs to the shadows after all.
137.context: NodeContext: Deep disappointment, almost to the point of heartbreak, that SH went the evil route.

297.speaker: Wyll
297.text: When the light shone through, I hoped she'd follow it.

144.speaker: Wyll
144.text: I'd pity the man who must bear the rage the Nightsong brings to bear, if that man weren't Ketheric Thorm.
144.context: NodeContext: A bit flustered to meet his hero Minsc.

5.speaker: Wyll
5.text: I bet Shadowheart's still wondering if she did the right thing. As for me, I haven't a shadow of a doubt.

145.speaker: Wyll
145.text: Who among us hasn't wondered what it would be like to live forever?
145.context: NodeContext: A bit flustered to meet his hero Minsc.

251.speaker: Wyll
251.text: You githyanki live for this very ideal, yes? To be welcomed home and live eternally in the Astral.

74.speaker: Wyll
74.text: But I think Jaheira's got the right idea. Better I live fully and meaningfully than to pine for an always-and-forever I could never achieve.

146.speaker: Wyll
146.text: Shar's domain, indeed. Despair and discarded memories, lurking in every shadow.
146.context: NodeContext: A bit flustered to meet his hero Minsc.

147.speaker: Wyll
147.text: I had another dream last night. The visitor came to me, and ordered me to penetrate the heart of the very cult that's spreading the infection.
147.context: NodeContext: A bit flustered to meet his hero Minsc.

85.speaker: Wyll
85.text: It gave me a tadpole gift, too. Just like it did the first time it appeared. I suppose it hoped this would help.

242.speaker: Wyll
242.text: At first I thought we should avoid these 'gifts', no matter what advantage we gain.

365.speaker: Wyll
365.text: And yet... I can't help recall the words of my father. 'The best plan is the one that works.'

265.speaker: Wyll
265.text: These powers could be enough to edge us towards victory.

79.speaker: Player
79.text: We need these powers to infiltrate the cult. This is 'the plan that works'.

358.speaker: Wyll
358.text: Very well. If it's mind games these parasites wish to play, we'll play. And we'll win.

198.speaker: Player
198.text: I'd sooner avoid these powers if we can. I feel like we're being led into a trap.

136.speaker: Wyll
136.text: Then we'd do well to walk around it. Use these powers sparingly, if you must use them at all.

154.speaker: Wyll
154.text: Damn it all, the spawn got exactly what they came for. But that doesn't mean I'm not going to fight back.
154.context: NodeContext: A bit flustered to meet his hero Minsc.

380.speaker: Wyll
380.text: Get your gear in order and rest up. We've got an undead elf to go recue.

158.speaker: Wyll
158.text: The Undercity. Father always warned me not to go poking around here - and for very good reason.
158.context: NodeContext: A bit flustered to meet his hero Minsc.

160.speaker: Wyll
160.text: This crown seems too powerful and dangerous an object for mere mortals to possess.
160.context: NodeContext: A bit flustered to meet his hero Minsc.

14.speaker: Wyll
14.text: Too dangerous, even, for Mystra. But I would sooner trust it with a god than a man.

161.speaker: Wyll
161.text: Power. Is that not what it is always about? Ketheric, Gortash, and now Viconia.
161.context: NodeContext: A bit flustered to meet his hero Minsc.

348.speaker: Wyll
348.text: The seed of tyranny begins with the want for power. Nurture it, let it grow, and we become the very despots we once despised.

163.speaker: Wyll
163.text: Quite an explosive secret to keep to yourself, Gale.
163.context: NodeContext: A bit flustered to meet his hero Minsc.

114.speaker: Wyll
114.text: And it seems Mystra's offered you an equally explosive solution. A shame my first brush with the famed Elminster couldn't be a tad more... optimistic.

166.speaker: Wyll
166.text: Listen, Gale - I might invoke the Triad from time to time, appeal to Helm. But I'm no man of faith. Not like you.

210.speaker: Wyll
210.text: I don't know what drives a man to consider his own death, among countless others, to be an appropriate exchange for his goddess' forgiveness.

323.speaker: Wyll
323.text: To me, it all sounds like nonsense.

105.speaker: Wyll
105.text: The faith that matters is that which you hold in yourself, in the ones that most matter to you.

31.speaker: Wyll
31.text: Big bomb be damned, you've got everything you need to defeat the Absolute already: Talent, nerve, and powerful allies at your side.

165.speaker: Wyll
165.text: I can't blame Halsin for leaving. We could have, should have, done more for him and for the cursed lands.
165.context: NodeContext: A bit flustered to meet his hero Minsc.

327.speaker: Wyll
327.text: They may never again feel the breathe of life on them. What a shame.

169.speaker: Wyll
169.text: By Balduran's bones, this is a lot to take in. Let's see if I've got this right:
169.context: NodeContext: A bit flustered to meet his hero Minsc.

336.speaker: Wyll
336.text: One: We've been carrying a mind flayer around with us this whole time.

212.speaker: Wyll
212.text: Two: It's been appearing as someone else in our dreams, cajoling us to embrace our new illithid talents.

206.speaker: Wyll
206.text: Three: The mind flayer's been siphoning a githyanki prisoner's powers to shield us from the Absolute's voice.

223.speaker: Player
223.text: He's just any githyanki. He's Mother Gith's son, living proof of Vlaakith's enduring lies.

189.speaker: Player
189.text: He's not just any githyanki. He's Mother Gith's faithless son, traitor to Queen Vlaakith.

60.speaker: Wyll
60.text: Ah yes - the wayward prince, locked away by the queen who would wield his power.

7.speaker: Player
7.text: Well, there's the matter of Duke Stelmane and the Knights of the Shield.

23.speaker: Wyll
23.text: How could I forget? One of Baldur's Gate's most distinguished figures, a mind flayer's ally.

231.speaker: Wyll
231.text: Sensational tales, aren't they? Almost unbelievable. With a narrator so unreliable, how do we tell fact from fiction?

15.speaker: Wyll
15.text: I can't pretend I have the answer. But I know the illithid's right about one thing:

42.speaker: Wyll
42.text: It holds our fates in its talons. Until the Absolute falls, there's no getting rid of it.

411.speaker: Player
411.text: He's not just any githyanki, but a prince who opposed the githyanki queen.

349.speaker: Wyll
349.text: Ah, yes - Gith's only son, locked away in his astral prison for defying Vlaakith.

175.speaker: Player
175.text: I think you've covered the broad strokes.

32.speaker: Player
32.text: I'm not sure I've wrapped my head around any of this.

360.speaker: Wyll
360.text: Understandable. Every tale was more sensational than the last. With a narrator so unreliable, how do we tell fact from fiction?

10.speaker: Player
10.text: He's not just any githyanki. He's a prince, the son of Great Mother Gith.

170.speaker: Wyll
170.text: Its light holds off every shadow. Keep close to the creature, lest the shadows devour us.
170.context: NodeContext: A bit flustered to meet his hero Minsc.

171.speaker: Wyll
171.text: Graven idols, cindered air. Bhaal's bloodied hands moulded this place.
171.context: NodeContext: A bit flustered to meet his hero Minsc.

172.speaker: Wyll
172.text: How beautiful it must be, to know you can hold a hand, to caress a cheek, after going so long without.
172.context: NodeContext: A bit flustered to meet his hero Minsc.

289.speaker: Wyll
289.text: And how terrible, to know your time to enjoy it is so short.

141.speaker: Wyll
141.text: We'll get Karlach fixed up, right? There's always a way - there has to be.

174.speaker: Wyll
174.text: If that wizard wants Dame Aylin so bad, I say we give him exactly what he's asked for.
174.context: NodeContext: A bit flustered to meet his hero Minsc.

9.speaker: Wyll
9.text: I'd love nothing more than to see her grind that wretch into bonedust.

176.speaker: Wyll
176.text: Father taught me to come to terms with my mortality. Mizora forced me to come to terms with a hellish fate.
176.context: NodeContext: A bit flustered to meet his hero Minsc.

185.speaker: Wyll
185.text: But to be destined for madness? I don't know if I could ever make peace with it.

311.speaker: Wyll
311.text: I don't envy you. But for what it's worth, I'm still at your side. And for now, I'm not going anywhere.

179.speaker: Wyll
179.text: Lae'zel is a powderkeg - and Shadowheart was the spark.
179.context: NodeContext: A bit flustered to meet his hero Minsc.

353.speaker: Wyll
353.text: If she points a blade at one of us again, don't hesitate to strike. We can afford no more unrest among us, not if we're to survive long enough to rid ourselves of these worms.

181.speaker: Wyll
181.text: The githyanki curing device seems set on killing us instead. I really had hoped...
181.context: NodeContext: A bit flustered to meet his hero Minsc.

183.speaker: Wyll
183.text: Hells. Is this really what you've become - the kind of monster I once vowed to slay?
183.context: NodeContext: A bit flustered to meet his hero Minsc.

182.speaker: Wyll
182.text: Don't bother answering - I already know.

184.speaker: Wyll
184.text: Shar called Shadowheart 'nothing.' But I know better than that.
184.context: NodeContext: A bit flustered to meet his hero Minsc.

117.speaker: Wyll
117.text: She is something. She is worthy, she is strong. She is Shadowheart.

249.speaker: Wyll
249.text: Nothing can take the her from her. Not even a goddess.

188.speaker: Wyll
188.text: So you went through with it. You returned Shadowheart to Viconia.
188.context: NodeContext: A bit flustered to meet his hero Minsc.

372.speaker: Wyll
372.text: Her mind will be wiped, and Viconia will remake her in whatever image she desires.

250.speaker: Wyll
250.text: A cruel fate, and for what? An unreliable ally in Viconia? Or just for the sheer cruelty of it?

113.speaker: Wyll
113.text: I hope you can come to terms with your choice. I'm not sure I'll ever be able to.

190.speaker: Wyll
190.text: The shadows are lifted. Finally, we can breathe free.
190.context: NodeContext: A bit flustered to meet his hero Minsc.

193.speaker: Wyll
193.text: Quite an explosive secret for Gale to keep to himself.
193.context: NodeContext: A bit flustered to meet his hero Minsc.

151.speaker: Wyll
151.text: And it seems Mystra's offered him an equally explosive solution. A shame our first brush with the famed Elminster couldn't be a tad more... optimistic.

70.speaker: Wyll
70.text: Listen - I might invoke the Triad from time to time, appeal to Helm. But I'm no man of faith. Not like Gale.

366.speaker: Wyll
366.text: I don't know what drives a man to consider his own death, among countless others, to be an appropriate exchange for his goddess' forgiveness.

177.speaker: Wyll
177.text: To me, it all sounds like nonsense.

22.speaker: Wyll
22.text: The faith that matters is that which you hold in yourself, in the ones that most matter to you.

80.speaker: Wyll
80.text: Big bomb be damned, Gale's got everything he needs to defeat the Absolute already: Talent, nerve, and powerful allies at his side.

284.speaker: Wyll
284.text: I hope he'll come to see that.

197.speaker: Wyll
197.text: So Astarion's gone for good. I'll miss his - well, let's call it 'charisma'.
197.context: NodeContext: A bit flustered to meet his hero Minsc.

199.speaker: Wyll
199.text: I trust that's the end of this silly quarrel? We'll have no energy for battling our enemies if we're too busy squabbling among ourselves.
199.context: NodeContext: A bit flustered to meet his hero Minsc.

204.speaker: Wyll
204.text: Onward - we cannot let the Nightsong do battle alone!
204.context: NodeContext: A bit flustered to meet his hero Minsc.

207.speaker: Wyll
207.text: The Gur was a monster hunter, not so different from me - and we slayed him on your behalf.
207.context: NodeContext: A bit flustered to meet his hero Minsc.

235.speaker: Wyll
235.text: I know better than to be disappointed in you - that ship has long sailed the Sea of Swords.

209.speaker: Wyll
209.text: No - I'm disappointed in me. For believing you were any different than what you always showed yourself to be.

213.speaker: Player
213.text: The Beloved Ranger. I - I can't believe it. I grew up hearing all about your brave deeds. And Boo's, of course.
213.context: NodeContext: A bit flustered to meet his hero Minsc.

153.speaker: Wyll
153.text: The Beloved Ranger. I - I can't believe it. I grew up hearing all about your brave deeds. And Boo's, of course.
153.context: NodeContext: A bit flustered to meet his hero Minsc.

139.speaker: Minsc
139.text: The bravery was mostly Boo's. Minsc simply followed with the shouting and waving of swords.

135.speaker: Wyll
135.text: My father told me all about how... how you struck down the mad cleric Bassilus, how -

40.speaker: Wyll
40.text: - goodness, my palms are all sweaty. It's just that - you were always my hero.

334.speaker: Player
334.text: Are you nervous about meeting your hero, Wyll?

162.speaker: Minsc
162.text: Do not drip so much, horn-headed one. Boo does not bite. Well, actually, he does. But only in the service of smiting evil.

276.speaker: Minsc
276.text: Do not drip so much, damp one. Boo does not bite. Well, actually, he does. But only in the service of smiting evil.

194.speaker: Player
194.text: Wyll is here is quite the hero in his own right, Minsc.

378.speaker: Wyll
378.text: I'm no hero. But I've dedicated my life to keeping the Sword Coast safe from the monsters that roam it.

202.speaker: Minsc
202.text: If that is not a hero, then Minsc and Boo are no heroes. You're not saying my hamster is not a hero, Wyll...?

72.speaker: Minsc
72.text: The saying matters not. Let it be a thing of doing - you will be blinded by Boo's obvious heroism when you smite evil by his side.

357.speaker: Player
357.text: What would your 'hero' think about how you killed Karlach, an innocent tiefling?

86.speaker: Wyll
86.text: Please understand - I thought she was a true devil. An agent of the archdevil Zariel.

48.speaker: Minsc
48.text: Devils. Ever do they try to sway the mind with the dangling temptations.

192.speaker: Minsc
192.text: Minsc himself was once almost swayed by a succubus, until Boo set to biting in particular places.

200.speaker: Minsc
200.text: Really and truly. Being swayed by evil does not count, so long as you are swift with the smiting afterwards.

148.speaker: Minsc
148.text: Blade of Smiting Evil Frontiers...? Eh. If it is all the same, Minsc and Boo will just call you Wyll.

76.speaker: Wyll
76.text: Oh ye gods. Never change, Minsc. Never change.

180.speaker: Player
180.text: And you then you pacted with a half-devil. What do you think of that, Minsc?

138.speaker: Minsc
138.text: I broke bread and evil bones with a child of Bhaal. Minsc is not so judgey as you, my friend, so long as Wyll's deed was done for good.

39.speaker: Wyll
39.text: I know it was. I gave my soul to so that the people of Baldur's Gate might live.

404.speaker: Narrator
404.text: *Your parasite tingles. Minsc knows that Wyll speaks true.*

99.speaker: Player
99.text: You should tell your hero how you exchanged your father's life for your soul.

49.speaker: Minsc
49.text: Wyll fights for good, does he not? It is not for Minsc or you to judge a hero like the Blade of Frontiers.

275.speaker: Narrator
275.text: *Your parasite tingles. Wyll's memories are laid out before the ranger.*

301.speaker: Minsc
301.text: Aha! I see a ring of devils, dangling temptation. And Wyll resisted - what evil is there in this?

215.speaker: Wyll
215.text: Ah - what a relief to have you back with us. Who doesn't enjoy a bit of pomp with their circumstance?
215.context: NodeContext: Sad - and the 'congratulations' is a sarcastic one.

218.speaker: Wyll
218.text: Dammit all, we've got to get Gale back. If that means killing Gortash, nothing would give me greater pleasure.
218.context: NodeContext: Sad - and the 'congratulations' is a sarcastic one.

416.speaker: Wyll
416.text: But we've got to tread carefully. I won't risk my father's life to take Gortash's.

220.speaker: Wyll
220.text: Shit. Every choice an impossible one, every consequence unknown.
220.context: NodeContext: Sad - and the 'congratulations' is a sarcastic one.

385.speaker: Wyll
385.text: Assimilate Orpheus for yourself, and you become illithid. The Emperor does it, and it claims the prince's power for himself.

203.speaker: Wyll
203.text: And then there's the Orphic Hammer. We could refuse the Emperor entirely and break Orpheus free.

13.speaker: Wyll
13.text: Were I to choose, I'd break the prince free. Better to entrust our fates to him before making an unneeded sacrifice - or entrusting Orpheus' power to the illithid.

391.speaker: Wyll
391.text: But this is your decision to make. Wherever you lead, I will follow.

221.speaker: Wyll
221.text: The agony of knowing the end is near.
221.context: NodeContext: Sad - and the 'congratulations' is a sarcastic one.

332.speaker: Wyll
332.text: I spent years swatting away my fears and doubts of my infernal fate - but I eventually made my peace. I had to.

258.speaker: Wyll
258.text: You will too, Karlach. I know it. Until then, I'm here every step of the way.

38.speaker: Wyll
38.text: You will too, Karlach. I know it.

106.speaker: Wyll
106.text: Karlach will, too. Just give her time.

222.speaker: Wyll
222.text: Shadowheart's gone, then - and I can't blame her. Let us try to take better care of each other.
222.context: NodeContext: Sad - and the 'congratulations' is a sarcastic one.

224.speaker: Wyll
224.text: I had a dream last night - a vivid one. And so did you, judging from the way my tadpole is tingling.
224.context: NodeContext: Sad - and the 'congratulations' is a sarcastic one.

159.speaker: Wyll
159.text: Someone came to me and promised to protect me while claiming that the parasite could empower me.

240.speaker: Wyll
240.text: Tempting as these powers sound, we should recognise this dream for what it is - the tadpoles' little trick.

150.speaker: Wyll
150.text: No good ever came from trusting honey-tongued strangers conjured up by illithid worms.

325.speaker: Player
325.text: I think we should hear out this dream figure. Maybe these 'powers' could be useful.

293.speaker: Wyll
293.text: I wouldn't advise it. Play with fire and you get burned. That's always the way of it.

191.speaker: Player
191.text: We should have as little to do with these tadpoles as we can.

28.speaker: Wyll
28.text: Well said. This dream figure is no friend to us.

228.speaker: Wyll
228.text: Congratulations - the amulet is yours. But don't think Valeria was the only soul you sacrificed to retrieve it.
228.context: NodeContext: Sad - and the 'congratulations' is a sarcastic one.

229.speaker: Wyll
229.text: I have battled great evils, been mocked by villains of all sorts. But Orin - she is beyond even Thorm. Her mind is twisted beyond recognition.

277.speaker: Wyll
277.text: What is she capable of? And where will she strike next?

230.speaker: Wyll
230.text: Gale slurped that thing up like a horse with a carrot. I hope he got what he needed from it.

238.speaker: Wyll
238.text: Today, a sacrifice must be made. I trust in you to lead us down the right path.

239.speaker: Wyll
239.text: Gone gods - watching you consume that tadpole was more disgusting than the tadpole itself.

143.speaker: Wyll
143.text: Though I suppose that's not what you wanted to talk about.

245.speaker: Wyll
245.text: You slurped that thing up like a horse with a carrot. I hope you got what you needed from it.

247.speaker: Wyll
247.text: Shit. It isn't over - Ketheric Thorm still lives.

257.speaker: Wyll
257.text: Too close for comfort - but thanks to some quick thinking, the githyanki crèche is still standing.

262.speaker: Wyll
262.text: This crown seems too powerful and dangerous an object for mere mortals to possess.

65.speaker: Wyll
65.text: Too dangerous, even, for Mystra. But I would sooner trust it with a god than with Gale.

263.speaker: Wyll
263.text: This crown seems too powerful and dangerous an object for mere mortals to possess, Gale.

125.speaker: Wyll
125.text: Too dangerous, even, for Mystra. But I would sooner trust it with a god than a man.

267.speaker: Wyll
267.text: My first tour of a githyanki crèche. Memorable, to be certain, but the service left something to be desired.

268.speaker: Wyll
268.text: We made our choice; there's no going back. Onward - the Netherbrain awaits.

269.speaker: Wyll
269.text: Mysterious, that Shadowheart - and mysteriously endearing. Behind those eyes lurk uncountable secrets.

271.speaker: Wyll
271.text: Let's dash for the exit, lest we suffer the full extent of Vlaakith's fury.

278.speaker: Wyll
278.text: Ah - Halsin is such a delight. Woe to the cultist who tangles with that thick hunk of an elf.

280.speaker: Wyll
280.text: I'd love nothing more than to smash Orpheus free with that hammer and cut out the illithid middleman.

355.speaker: Wyll
355.text: But I'm not convinced the githyanki prince wouldn't smash us to pieces given the chance.

281.speaker: Wyll
281.text: A shame my first brush with the famed Elminster couldn't be a tad more... optimistic.

285.speaker: Wyll
285.text: Our very own vampire's the missing pawn in his master's deadly game.

167.speaker: Wyll
167.text: Now how about we go and reverse Cazador's fortunes?

286.speaker: Wyll
286.text: The deathbringer Sarevok. He was made into ash - and from ash, it seems, he rose again.

288.speaker: Wyll
288.text: This place is astonishing, a bard's legend made real.

291.speaker: Wyll
291.text: Have you seen Astarion? He's positively glowing. Must've woke up on the good side of the bunk.

292.speaker: Wyll
292.text: The good news: we've got the Orphic Hammmer. The bad news: we have to get into the Astral Prism to use it.

234.speaker: Wyll
234.text: It's bound to happen. I just don't know when or how.

298.speaker: Wyll
298.text: Isobel, Selûne's light made real. And you slaughtered her like cattle and left Last Light for the shadows to feed on.

157.speaker: Wyll
157.text: I'd ask what's become of you. But perhaps this is who you've been all along.

225.speaker: Wyll
225.text: Either way, I mourn for the image of you I once held dear.

299.speaker: Wyll
299.text: The menacing githyanki machine and its jagged pincers held no cure at all. Who could've thought?

304.speaker: Wyll
304.text: This crown seems too powerful and dangerous an object for mere mortals to possess, Gale.

226.speaker: Wyll
226.text: Too dangerous, even, for Mystra. But I would sooner trust it with a god than a man - including you.

305.speaker: Wyll
305.text: I have seen the ravages visited on Toril by the gods. Even the ones we so naively call 'good'.

63.speaker: Wyll
63.text: If Gale's intentions are virtuous, ultimate power will sour them. And if they are not, well - I shudder to think of the chaos he could sow.

308.speaker: Wyll
308.text: Karlach's all fire and fury. I pray to the Triad it doesn't consume her.

309.speaker: Wyll
309.text: I've known wizards of Lorroakan's ilk. So sure of ignorance in everyone else, they can't fathom being fooled themselves.

26.speaker: Wyll
26.text: May Dame Aylin strike with surprise on her side. And may we be there to see it.

310.speaker: Wyll
310.text: Quite an explosive secret for Gale to keep to himself.

313.speaker: Wyll
313.text: I... hmm... oh! I seem to have forgotten myself, there.

316.speaker: Wyll
316.text: Balduran's bones - the githyanki crèche is naught but rubble, may the Triad have mercy.

317.speaker: Wyll
317.text: What's this I smell? Rotted eggs, clotted blood, and the overwhelming tang of sour cabbage.

321.speaker: Wyll
321.text: Love Shadowheart's new look. Softer, less severe. It suits her.

322.speaker: Wyll
322.text: Astarion showed restraint where most others wouldn't. He might not appreciate the sentiment - but I'm proud of him.

324.speaker: Wyll
324.text: All the tumbledown opulence of a withering Upper City manor.

236.speaker: Wyll
236.text: Raphael's house may be posh, but it's seen better days.

328.speaker: Wyll
328.text: Loyalty is one thing. Wilful ignorance is another.

274.speaker: Wyll
274.text: I'd like to say I respect Lae'zel's choice. But her faith has turned to fanaticism.

329.speaker: Wyll
329.text: All my time roaming the frontiers, and I'd seen neither hair nor hide of a githyanki.

98.speaker: Wyll
98.text: To think this crèche was nestled in the valley, a day's trot away.

330.speaker: Wyll
330.text: The Harpers have been compromised - a balancing power, now unbalanced.

142.speaker: Wyll
142.text: Jaheira's support has been invaluable. We should return it in kind.

333.speaker: Wyll
333.text: Shadowheart did what was right, knowing she stood to suffer for it. In so doing, she proved what it means to be a hero.

338.speaker: Wyll
338.text: The agony of knowing the end is near.

345.speaker: Wyll
345.text: I spent years swatting away my fears and doubts of my infernal fate - but I eventually made my peace. I had to.

104.speaker: Wyll
104.text: You will too, Karlach. I know it. Until then, I'm here every step of the way.

374.speaker: Wyll
374.text: You will too, Karlach. I know it.

339.speaker: Wyll
339.text: Alfira wouldn't have harmed a housefly. A gentle young soul, slain in her prime.

243.speaker: Wyll
243.text: Whoever the culprit, let it be known: I will not stand for more innocent blood being shed in our camp.

340.speaker: Wyll
340.text: There is no hell hot enough for a man like Gortash.

217.speaker: Wyll
217.text: He may be dead, but his tyranny still suffocates Balduran's grand city.

343.speaker: Wyll
343.text: Vampire spawn. One's proven enough, let alone a horde of them.

354.speaker: Wyll
354.text: By the gone gods. It isn't the blood you've spilled or the lives you've snuffed out that horrify me most.

82.speaker: Wyll
82.text: It's the pride you take in it, as if you've done all sixteen planes a great favour.

91.speaker: Wyll
91.text: When the Absolute falls, I wager our alliance falls with it.

359.speaker: Wyll
359.text: Come. We have a Netherbrain to tear up.

361.speaker: Wyll
361.text: Our very own vampire's the missing pawn in his master's deadly game.

364.speaker: Wyll
364.text: Minsc is being tricked. By the Hells, we've got to rip him away from that shapeshifter.

367.speaker: Wyll
367.text: My head throbs with every step. The closer the brain, the louder its call.

369.speaker: Wyll
369.text: Insert the artefact into the planecaster. I don't know about you, but I'm ready to see who - or what - is inside it.

371.speaker: Wyll
371.text: Karlach never ceases to amaze me.

270.speaker: Wyll
270.text: Death is staring her down. And she want these last moments to count for something.

116.speaker: Wyll
116.text: I can't bear to think of it. But I can't tell her 'no'.

121.speaker: Wyll
121.text: She'd become a mind flayer - but she'd lead us to a sure victory. It's what she does.

130.speaker: Wyll
130.text: If she wants to go make these last moments count, then don't hold her back.

373.speaker: Wyll
373.text: Hunt the monsters of the Sword Coast, protect the people - that was my promise.

259.speaker: Wyll
259.text: Killing Astarion was the right thing to do. I have to believe that.

303.speaker: Wyll
303.text: But I'm not proud of it. Not after... all this.

381.speaker: Wyll
381.text: Orin's game is abduction, is it? Well - we can't stand idly by. We've got an ally to rescue.

386.speaker: Wyll
386.text: Taken from the light to be raised in darkness.

356.speaker: Wyll
356.text: The truth is finally dawning. Shadowheart can follow its light - or she can retreat back into dusk.

388.speaker: Wyll
388.text: Gale's glowing with magic. Mystra must be mighty happy right about now.

389.speaker: Wyll
389.text: I have seen the ravages visited on Toril by the gods, Gale. Even the ones we so naively call 'good'.

256.speaker: Wyll
256.text: If your intentions are virtuous, ultimate power will sour them. And if they are not, well - I shudder to think of the chaos you could sow.

390.speaker: Wyll
390.text: Shadowheart did what was right, knowing she stood to suffer for it. In so doing, she proved what it means to be a hero.

393.speaker: Wyll
393.text: Thousands were sacrificed, and the servant become lord. I am sure Astarion's quite pleased with himself.

315.speaker: Wyll
315.text: Wish I could say the same.

395.speaker: Wyll
395.text: Well - I'll cross this place off our list off possible holiday destinations.

397.speaker: Wyll
397.text: Who among us hasn't wondered what it would be like to live forever?

196.speaker: Wyll
196.text: But I think you've got the right idea. Better I live fully and meaningfully than to pine for an always-and-forever I could never achieve.

398.speaker: Wyll
398.text: You never cease to amaze me.

27.speaker: Wyll
27.text: Death is staring you down. And so you want these last moments to count for something.

73.speaker: Wyll
73.text: I can't bear to think of it. But I can't tell you 'no'.

403.speaker: Wyll
403.text: You'd become a mind flayer - but you'd lead us to a sure victory. It's what you do.

394.speaker: Wyll
394.text: But if assimilation is your choice, I won't stop you. I never would.

399.speaker: Wyll
399.text: I fear we have no choice. What I ask is unreasonable by every standard. It sickens me to think, let alone say, but -

384.speaker: Wyll
384.text: If someone must assimilate Orpheus, I'd sooner trust you with the power than the illithid...

152.speaker: Wyll
152.text: You'd become a mind flayer - an incredible sacrifice. If you refuse, I'd understand. Of course I would.

68.speaker: Wyll
68.text: That's where I stand. But whatever you do, I trust you to the last.

400.speaker: Wyll
400.text: Maybe Gale should avoid items laced with dark magic. 'You are what you eat', as the old adage goes.

401.speaker: Wyll
401.text: The seat of the Iron Throne was razed a century ago - or so it was said.

186.speaker: Wyll
186.text: Terrible to think of the atrocities these walls have been witness to.

402.speaker: Wyll
402.text: Mystra wants to meet Gale? Impressive. The only thing a god's ever offered me is a cold shoulder.

407.speaker: Wyll
407.text: Hm - the place is remarkably well-kept, as underground lairs go.

408.speaker: Wyll
408.text: A shame my first brush with the famed Elminster couldn't be a tad more... optimistic.

409.speaker: Wyll
409.text: Lae'zel's suspicion and Shadowheart's guile made for a lethal combination. I fear for our fellowship, if trust is in such short supply.

414.speaker: Wyll
414.text: There's a schism growing among the githyanki people. And Lae'zel just took one step towards choosing a side.

417.speaker: Wyll
417.text: I trust that's the end of this silly quarrel? We'll have no energy for battling our enemies if we're too busy squabbling among ourselves.
